title: 105_s674
content: The "Children's Health Insurance Provides Security (CHIPS) Act of 1997" encourages states to expand Medicaid coverage for children and pregnant women by increasing the Federal Medical Assistance Percentage (FMAP). The FMAP for Medical Assistance for Certain Individuals under the Social Security Act is increased for states that meet specific conditions, providing enhanced medical assistance percentage for optional coverage groups. The plan includes coverage for individuals under 19 years of age and continuous eligibility for 12 months. Optional coverage groups include pregnant women with family income between 133-150 percent of the poverty line. The plan provides coverage for pregnant women, infants, and children under 6 years old with family incomes between 133-150 percent of the poverty line. Older children with family incomes between 100-150 percent of the poverty line are also covered. The plan covers pregnant women, infants, and children under 6 years old with family incomes between 133-150 percent of the poverty line. Older children with family incomes between 100-150 percent of the poverty line are also included. States have the option to expand eligibility to 150 percent of the poverty line. The state has the option to expand eligibility for children over 1 year of age to 150 percent of the poverty line. Additionally, states can cover all children under 19 years of age and provide continuous eligibility for 12 months. The state has the option to provide continuous eligibility for children under 19 years of age for up to 12 months after determination of eligibility, effective January 1, 1998. SEC. 3. EMPLOYER CONTRIBUTIONS TO PREMIUMS. Employers making contributions for health insurance coverage cannot discriminate based on an individual's eligibility for medical assistance. Ceasing contributions for all employees does not violate this rule. Enforcement provisions from the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 apply. Enforcement provisions from the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 apply to employers violating this section. SEC. 4. GRANT PROGRAM TO PROMOTE OUTREACH EFFORTS. Authorization of Appropriations for outreach efforts to enroll eligible children under Medicaid and related programs. $25,000,000 annually for grants to States, localities, and nonprofits. Funds can be used for training and administrative costs, including implementing a common application form for federal child assistance programs. The application forms under the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1989 are used to determine eligibility for assistance under the Medicaid program and other federal child assistance programs. This includes programs like temporary assistance for needy families, the food stamp program, and foster care maintenance payments. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1989 application forms determine eligibility for Medicaid and federal child assistance programs. Funding under this section requires approval of an application by a State, locality, or nonprofit entity, with eligibility workers stationed at sites where children receive health care services. The Secretary may administer the grant program to promote coordination of Medicaid and child health activities.
